Principles of Uncertainty Erik Štrumbelj 2019-04-04 Preface These are the course notes for the Principles of uncertainty course of the Data Science Master’s at University of Ljubljana, Faculty of computer and information science.
Chapter 1 Introduction 1.1 Outcomes and events 1.2 Further reading and references 1.3 Learning outcomes 1.4 Practice problems

Chapter 1 Introduction Note: Murphy:Ch01 covers most of the in this chapter material really well (and with much more supporting material and examples), although some definitions are slightly different. Wasserman:Ch06 is a very nice complementary reference for definition of model, parametric and nonparametric. Uncertainty - a lack of complete information about something - can be the result of many things. In the context of Probability and Statistics courses uncertainty is often synonymous with the randomness of the studied phenomena. However, that need not always be the case. Incomplete information could also be due to lack of knowledge, ignorance, or just plain laziness. Whatever the reason might be for our uncertainty, quantitative reasoning with uncertainty requires us to give a complete and precise description of the studied phenomena and the uncertainty. Informally, the minimal amount of structure we need is a description of all possible truths’, a set of all events - subsets of possible truths that we allow ourselves to assign uncertainty to, and an assignment of uncertainty to each event. The formalism we will use throughout the course is a probability space - a triplet that formalizes what can informally be stated as 1.1 Outcomes and events 1.2 Further reading and references 1.3 Learning outcomes Data science students should work towards obtaining the knowledge and the skills that enable them to: Classify real world problems into subtasks of machine learning. Distinguish between parametric and nonparametric models and describe their characteristics. Recognize which set of solutions (which hypothesis) we restrict ourselves to by selecting a particular model. Identify which aspects of model utility (error, interpretability, computation speed) are more important for the problem at hand. Describe the concepts curse of dimensionality and no free lunch and their implications for practical work. 1.4 Practice problems some practice problems? (=homework)
